April 11, 2010: Fiction
CAUGHT, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $27.95.) A suburban girl goes missing.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
HOUSE RULES, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $28.) A teenage boy with Asperger’s
syndrome is accused of murder.
THE SILENT SEA, by Clive Cussler and Jack Du Brul. (Putnam, $27.95.) Juan
Cabrillo and the crew of the Oregon make discoveries that lead back to an ancient
Chinese expedition.
BITE ME, by Christopher Moore. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $23.99.) Saving San
Francisco from a vampyre cat.
ABRAHAM LINCOLN: VAMPIRE HUNTER, by Seth Grahame-Smith. (Grand
Central, $21.99.) Lincoln fights the undead; by the author of “Pride and Prejudice
and Zombies."
MATTERHORN, by Karl Marlantes. (El León Literary Arts/Atlantic Monthly,
$24.95.) Marines in Vietnam in 1969.
THINK TWICE, by Lisa Scottoline. (St. Martin’s, $26.99.) A woman takes over her
twin sister’s life.
SHATTERED, by Karen Robards. (Putnam, $25.95.) Investigating a cold case
about a family that disappeared in 1981, a woman discovers that she resembles
the missing girl.
ANGELOLOGY, by Danielle Trussoni. (Viking, $27.95.) A nun is drawn into an
ancient struggle against the Nephilim, hybrid offspring of humans and heavenly
beings.
WORST CASE, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) A New York detective raising 10 children alone investigates a string of
kidnappings and killings of teenagers by a villain with unusual motives.
THE MAPPING OF LOVE AND DEATH, by Jacqueline Winspear.
(Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99.) In 1932, the psychologist Maisie Dobbs searches
for the nurse who wrote love letters to a young cartographer killed in World War I.
SPLIT IMAGE, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $25.95.) Jesse Stone, the police
chief of Paradise, Mass., copes with divorce, the bottle and the murder of a mob
soldier.
THE LOST SYMBOL, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $29.95.) Robert Langdon
among the Masons.
April 11, 2010
Non-Fiction
THE BIG SHORT, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $27.95.) The people who saw the
real estate crash coming and made billions from their foresight.
CHELSEA CHELSEA BANG BANG, by Chelsea Handler. (Grand Central,
$25.99.) More humorous personal essays from the comedian.
THE PACIFIC, by Hugh Ambrose. (NAL Caliber, $26.95.) Stories of Marines and a
Navy pilot during World War II; companion volume for an HBO mini-series.
CHANGE YOUR BRAIN, CHANGE YOUR BODY, by Daniel G. Amen. (Harmony,
$25.99.) Using the brain-body connection to lose weight and avoid depression.
COURAGE AND CONSEQUENCE, by Karl Rove. (Threshold Editions, $30.)
President George W. Bush’s senior adviser and deputy chief of staff explains his
choices.
AMERICAN CONSPIRACIES, by Jesse Ventura with Dick Russell. (Skyhorse,
$24.95.) The former Minnesota governor questions the official explanation of
events like the Kennedy assassination and 9/11.
GAME CHANGE, by John Heilemann and Mark Halperin. (Harper/HarperCollins,
$27.99.) Behind the scenes in 2008.
THE IMMORTAL LIFE OF HENRIETTA LACKS, by Rebecca Skloot. (Crown,
$26.) The story of the woman whose cancer cells were cultured without her
permission in 1951.
NO APOLOGY, by Mitt Romney. (St. Martin’s, $25.99.) The former Massachusetts
governor and Republican presidential candidate calls for economic and civic
revitalization.
HAVE A LITTLE FAITH, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $23.99.) Lessons about the
comfort of belief.
WHERE MERCY IS SHOWN, MERCY IS GIVEN, by Duane Chapman with Laura
Morton. (Hyperion, $26.) Dog the Bounty Hunter’s personal story.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed, from the author of “Blink.”
LIES THE GOVERNMENT TOLD YOU, by Andrew P. Napolitano. (Thomas
Nelson, $24.99.) The deterioration of American freedom.
THE DEVIL’S CASINO, by Vicky Ward. (Wiley, $27.95.) Inside Lehman Brothers.
STONES INTO SCHOOLS, by Greg Mortenson. (Viking, $26.95.) Building
schools, many of them for girls, in northeast Afghanistan; takes up where “Three
